column3: Woman must receive information on accessing ultrasound services
column4: Provision of ultrasound required for abortion and the provider must display and describe image
column5: Provision of ultrasound required for abortion and provider must offer woman opportunity to view image
column6: If ultrasound is performed as part of preparation for abortion, provider must offer woman opportunity to view image
column7: Provision of ultrasound must be offered by provider to woman

column1: Some states have passed laws and policies that require a woman seeking an abortion to receive information on accessing ultrasound services, while others require that a woman undergo an ultrasound before an abortion. Routine ultrasound is not considered medically necessary as a component of a first-trimester abortion.
For more information about state legislation regarding Ultrasound Requirements click [here](http://www.guttmacher.org/statecenter/updates/index.html#ultrasound).
Guttmacher Institute, State Policies in Brief, [Requirements for Ultrasound](http://www.guttmacher.org/statecenter/spibs/spib_RFU.pdf), as of April 1, 2017.
1. If performed, an ultrasound must take place 24 hours in advance of the abortion; in Texas and Virginia some women must obtain the ultrasound at least 24 hours in advance.
2. Woman must be provided with verbal information on accessing ultrasound services.
3. Woman must be provided with written information on accessing ultrasound services. In Michigan, information is included in written counseling materials but not specifically mandated by law.
4. The law allows the woman look away from the image and in Louisiana, Texas and Virginia the woman may decline to listen to the description under certain circumstances.
5. If an ultrasound is requested by the woman, the provider will also display the image so that the woman can view it.
6. This law is permanently enjoined by court order; policy not in effect.
7. The provider must test for the fetal heartbeat which requires an ultrasound if the woman is in the first trimester of pregnancy.
8. The woman will also be offered the option to hear a detailed description of the image.
9. In Virginia and Wisconsin, a woman who has been sexually assaulted is not required to undergo the ultrasound.
